citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
***On or about April 1, 2023, in the Ring-tailed Lemur enclosure, a baby Lemur was found on the floor of the enclosure by
the general public. The owners of the facility were notified and immediately responded to the enclosure to find the male
and female Lemurs jumping up and down on the baby. The female was a first time mother according to the licensee. The
baby Lemur was immediately removed from the enclosure and found to still be alive. Measures of warming and
stimulation were performed by the staff, but baby Lemur died a short time after being removed from the enclosure. A
veterinarian was not contacted. The licensee stated that they were unaware that the female was pregnant, that staff
members had made a walk through check of the enclosures, but had not gotten to that enclosure for cleaning yet that
morning. No baby Lemur was seen at the time of the walk though prior to opening to the public, according to the licensee.
Lack of observation of breeding conditions in animals can lead to issues during pregnancy or at birth and a lack of timely
and accurate communication with the veterinarian.
The licensee has since contacted the attended veterinarian for the female Lemur and has ended the possibility of further
breeding.
The licensee must continue to observe animals conditions so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal
health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian.
These corrections were made by April 23, 2023 and must continue.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Critical
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
***On or about April 1, 2023, in the Ring-tailed Lemur enclosure, a baby Lemur was found on the floor of the enclosure by 
the general public. The owners of the facility were notified and immediately responded to the enclosure to find the male 
and female Lemurs jumping up and down on the baby. The female was a first time mother according to the licensee. The 
baby Lemur was immediately removed from the enclosure and found to still be alive. Measures of warming and 
stimulation were performed by the staff, but baby Lemur died a short time after being removed from the enclosure. A 
veterinarian was not contacted. The licensee stated that they were unaware that the female was pregnant, that staff 
members had made a walk through check of the enclosures, but had not gotten to that enclosure for cleaning yet that 
morning. No baby Lemur was seen at the time of the walk though prior to opening to the public, according to the licensee.  
Lack of observation of breeding conditions in animals can lead to issues during pregnancy or at birth and a lack of timely 
and accurate communication with the veterinarian.   
The licensee has since contacted the attended veterinarian for the female Lemur and has ended the possibility of further 
breeding. 
The licensee must continue to observe animals conditions so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal 
health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian. 
These corrections were made by April 23, 2023 and must continue.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
 n

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
